member.name: T:Remotion.Context.SafeContext
member.summary: Superior alternative to the and for making member variables thread safe that also works with ASP.NET threads.

remarks.para: The data managed by this class is by default stored in the , but the storage provider can be replaced by application code if needed. Replacements for the storage provider must guarantee that all data stored by the is thread-local.

The Remotion.Web assembly by default replaces the storage provider with one that stores all data in the . This ensures that works as expected in ASP.NET environments when a session migrates between threads.

member.threadsafety: The data managed by this class is thread-local. The class is safe to be used from multiple threads at the same time, but each thread will have its own copy of the data.

member.name: T:Remotion.Reflection.MemberSignatures.MethodSignature
member.summary: Represents a method signature and allows signatures to be compared to each other.

remarks.para: This class does not support closed generic methods, only generic method definitions are supported.
The signature currently does not include custom modifiers.

For simplicity, this class assumes that type or namespace names cannot contain the character "[". It also assumes that the full name of a type (namespace, enclosing type (if any), and simple type name) is enough to identify a type - assembly information is not used when comparing signatures.

member.summary: Defines the lifetime of instances of a type managed by a service locator.

member.name: F:Remotion.ServiceLocation.LifetimeKind.Singleton
member.summary: One instance is created and then reused every time an instance of the type is requested. This is the most efficient , and it should be used whenever possible. However, in cases where the service locator is used from multiple threads, the lifetime kind requires the instantiated type to be safe for multi-threading. Use when an implementation is not thread-safe.

member.name: F:Remotion.ServiceLocation.LifetimeKind.Instance
member.summary: A new instance is created every time an instance of the type is requested. This is the simplest and works well even in multi-threaded environments, but it might not be the most efficient one. Use for more efficiency.

member.name: T:Remotion.Logging.ILog
member.summary: The interface declares methods for logging messages.
member.remarks:
The interface is intended for implementing adapters to various logging frameworks.
The range of valid event ids is only guarenteed within the range of unsigned 16-bit integers.
Implementors must support event ids within the range of unsigned 16-bit integers. The behavior outside this range is can be either truncation of the event id or an . Implementors must ensure that the log message is logged before an is thrown.

member.name: T:Remotion.Reflection.ActionInvokerWrapper
member.summary: Used to wrap an object rather than returning it directly.

member.name: T:Remotion.Reflection.IActionInvoker
member.summary: This interface allows invokers with fixed arguments to be returned without references to their generic argument types.

remarks.p: Note that casting a to an interface is a boxing operation, thus creating an object on the heap and garbage collecting it later. For very performance-critical scenarios, it be better to avoid this and accept the references to the invoker's generic argument types.

It is recommended to wrap this interface within a , because returning an interface could lead to ambigous castings if the final call to is missing, while using structs will usually lead to a compile-time error as expected.

member.name: T:Remotion.Reflection.FuncInvokerWrapper`1
member.summary: Used to wrap an object rather than returning it directly.
member.typeparam: Return type of the method that will be invoked.

member.name: T:Remotion.Reflection.IFuncInvoker`1
member.summary: This interface allows invokers with fixed arguments to be returned without references to their generic argument types.

remarks.p: Note that casting a struct to an interface is a boxing operation, thus creating an object on the heap and garbage collecting it later. For very performance-critical scenarios, it be better to avoid this and accept the references to the invoker's generic argument types.

It is recommended to wrap this interface within a , because returning an interface could lead to ambigous castings if the final call to is missing, while using structs will usually lead to a compile-time error as expected.

member.typeparam: Return type of the method that will be invoked.

member.name: T:Remotion.ServiceLocation.SafeServiceLocator
member.summary: is intended as a wrapper for , specifically the property. In contrast to , will never throw a but instead register an default instance if no custom service locator was registered.

remarks.para:
Accessing will always lead to a if no service locator is configured. Using instead will catch the exception and register a default instance. A provider for the default instance can be defined in the application configuration file (handled by ). The provider needs to implement and must have a default constructor.
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8" ?> <configuration> <configSections> <section name="remotion.serviceLocation" type="Remotion.Configuration.ServiceLocation.ServiceLocationConfiguration,Remotion" /> </configSections>
<remotion.serviceLocation xmlns="http://www.re-motion.org/serviceLocation/configuration"> <serviceLocatorProvider type="MyAssembly::MyServiceLocatorProvider"/> </remotion.serviceLocation> </configuration>
If no provider is configured, a instance is used as the default instance.

member.name: P:Remotion.ServiceLocation.SafeServiceLocator.Current
member.summary: Gets the currently configured . If no service locator is configured or returns , a default will be returned as defined by the .
member.remarks: When this property is accessed while the default instance is built (triggered through an outer access to this property), it will return a bootstrapping service locator that behaves just like . This means that the code building the default can indeed access the property without triggering any exceptions. To configure the bootstrapping , use the property.

member.name: P:Remotion.ServiceLocation.SafeServiceLocator.BootstrapConfiguration
member.summary: Allows clients to register services that are available while the is built. These service registrations are also passed on to the so that they can be incorporated in the final .

remarks.para: When the property is accessed for the first time, and no provider has been set via , a default is built as defined by the . Building the default provider, which may include construction of an IoC container, can be a complex operation. When the code building the default locator accesses the property, it will get a reference to a bootstrapping , which behaves just like the (i.e., it evaluates declarations and such). The allows clients to register additional services with the bootstrapping .

member.name: T:Remotion.Collections.SetBasedCacheKey`1
member.summary: Takes a set of objects and provides value-type semantics to the set, so that it can be used as a cache key.

remarks.para: This type implements by calculating the hash codes of all elements in the set wrapped by this collection and combining them in an (order-independent) way. Therefore, two instances of this type give the same hash codes if the elements wrapped by them give the same hash codes. It is not guaranteed that two instances of this type give different hash codes if the elements give different hash codes.
Similarly, is implemented by comparing the elements of the sets with each other. Two instances of this type compare equal if and only if they contain equal objects (without considering order).
For efficiency, the hash codes of instances of this type are cached. Changes to the objects wrapped by an instance do not influance the hash code and should therefore be avoided.
Note that, because this type is based on , equal elements are regarded as one. This is, a set (1, 1, 2, 2) is equivalent to a set (1, 2).

member.name: T:Remotion.Diagnostics.OuterProductProcessingState
member.summary: The current state of the outer product / nested for loops traversal. DimensionIndices supplies the current permutation of indices (array with an entry for each for-loop). DimensionIndex is the currently running for-loop; ElementIndex (=DimensionIndices[DimensionIndex]) is the value of the loop-variable of the currently running for-loop. IsInnermostLoop, IsOutermostLoop can be queried to treat the innermost and outermost loop differently, if so required.

member.name: M:Remotion.Diagnostics.OuterProductProcessingState.#ctor(Remotion.Diagnostics.OuterProductIndexGenerator,System.Int32)
member.summary: Initializes a ProcessingState with an OuterProductIndexGenerator reference and the current dimension index (= nested-for-loop loop-variable index).

member.name: M:Remotion.Diagnostics.OuterProductProcessingState.GetDimensionIndicesCopy
member.summary: Returns a copy of the current -array. Use if you want to e.g. store the generated dimension indices permutations in your own collection.

member.name: P:Remotion.Diagnostics.OuterProductProcessingState.DimensionIndex
member.summary: The outer product dimension which is currently processed (i.e. the index of the currently running for-loop).

member.name: P:Remotion.Diagnostics.OuterProductProcessingState.NumberElementsPerDimension
member.summary: Integer array containing the number of elements in each outer product dimension.

member.name: P:Remotion.Diagnostics.OuterProductProcessingState.DimensionIndices
member.summary: Integer array containing the current permutation of outer product indices (i.e. each array entry is the current value of each for-loop variable; ).

member.name: P:Remotion.Diagnostics.OuterProductProcessingState.NumberElementsOverall
member.summary: The overall number of elements in the outer product.

member.name: P:Remotion.Diagnostics.OuterProductProcessingState.ElementIndex
member.summary: ElementIndex (=DimensionIndices[DimensionIndex]) is the value of the loop-variable of the currently running for-loop.

member.name: P:Remotion.Diagnostics.OuterProductProcessingState.IsFirstLoopElement
member.summary: Whether the element is the first element in the current for-loop.

member.name: P:Remotion.Diagnostics.OuterProductProcessingState.IsLastLoopElement
member.summary: Whether the element is the last element in the current for-loop.

member.name: P:Remotion.Diagnostics.OuterProductProcessingState.IsInnermostLoop
member.summary: Whether the current for-loop is the innermost loop.

member.name: P:Remotion.Diagnostics.OuterProductProcessingState.IsOutermostLoop
member.summary: Whether the current for-loop is the outermost loop.

member.name: P:Remotion.Diagnostics.OuterProductProcessingState.NumberElementsProcessed
member.summary: The overall elements of the outer product which have already been processed.

member.name: T:Remotion.ExtensibleEnums.ExtensibleEnum`1
member.summary: Base class for extensible enums. Create extensible enums by deriving a class representing the enumeration from and define extension methods on to define the values of the enumeration. Each value is uniquely identified by the string passed to the constructor. Value comparisons act solely based on this identifier.
member.remarks: Instances of this class should be immutable, i.e. they should not change once initialized. This is due to their value semantics (a value retrieved from a cache should not be distinguishable from a value freshly created by an extension method call) and leads to inherent thread-safety.

member.name: T:Remotion.ServiceLocation.DefaultServiceLocator
member.summary: Provides a default implementation of the interface based on the . The uses (and registers) an instance of this class unless an application registers its own service locator via .

remarks.para: This implementation of uses the to resolve implementations of "service types" (usually interfaces or abstract classes). When the is asked to get an instance of a specific service type for the first time, that type is checked for a , which is then inspected to determine the actual concrete type to be instantiated, its lifetime, and similar properties. An instance is then returned that fulfills the properties defined by the . After the first resolution of a service type, the instance (or a factory, depending on the associated with the type) is cached, so subsequent lookups for the same type are very fast.

The also provides a set of methods that allow to registration of custom implementations or factories for service types even if those types do not have the applied. Applications can use this to override the configuration defined by the and to register implementations of service types that do not have the applied. Custom implementations or factories must be registered before an instance of the respective service type is retrieved for the first time.

In order to be instantiable by the , a concrete type indicated by the must have exactly one public constructor. The constructor may have parameters, in which case the will try to get an instance for each of the parameters using the same methods. If a parameter cannot be resolved (because the parameter type has no applied and no custom implementation or factory was manually registered), an exception is thrown. Dependency cycles are not detected and will lead to a or infinite loop. Use the method to manually register a factory for types that do not apply to these constructor rules.
In order to have a custom service locator use the same defaults as the , the can be used to extract those defaults from a set of types.

member.name: T:Remotion.Reflection.TypeDiscovery.AssemblyLoading.FilteringAssemblyLoader
member.summary: Loads assemblies and applies filters before returning them. Assemblies are loaded from a file path by first getting their corresponding and then loading the assembly with that name. This means that only assemblies from the assembly search path (application directory, dynamic directory, GAC) can be loaded, and that GAC assemblies are preferred. The advantage of this load mode is that assemblies are loaded exactly the same way as if loaded directly by .NET: they are always loaded into the correct context and references are resolved correctly.
member.remarks: The assemblies loaded by this class can be filtered by implementations of .

member.name: T:Remotion.Collections.Set`1
member.summary: Implements a set collection data type.
member.typeparam: The type of items to be stored by this collection.

remarks.para: A is an unordered collection of items, where each item added is held exactly once. When an item is added more than once (determined by the given or the default comparer ), the set will automatically ignore the second add operation.
The data type is internally based on a , so checking whether a set contains an item is very fast, but depends on the quality of the hashing algorithm used for .
This collection type does not support items being , is not automatically safe for multi-threading, and cannot be set to be read-only.

member.name: T:Remotion.Reflection.TypeDiscovery.AssemblyLoading.ApplicationAssemblyLoaderFilter
member.summary: Filters the assemblies loaded during type discovery by name, excluding those whose names resemble system assemblies or assemblies generated by the mixin engine. In addition, assemblies that have the defined are also excluded. Note that assemblies have to be loaded in memory in order to check whether the attribute is present. This will also lock the assembly files.
member.remarks:
The name-based filtering by default excludes the following assembly name patterns:
mscorlib
System
System\..*
Microsoft\..*
Remotion\..*\.Generated\..*
This list might change in the future, and it can be extended via .

member.name: M:Remotion.Text.CommandLine.CommandLineParser.SplitCommandLine(System.String,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Splits a command line string into an array of command line arguments, separated by spaces.
member.param: The command line (as available from .)
member.returns: An array of command line arguments.
member.remarks:
The following rules apply:
Use spaces to separate arguments.
Embed arguments within double quotation marks to treat them as a single argument even if they contain spaces.
Within double quotation marks, use two double quotation marks if you need one double quotation mark in the argument.
This resembles the logic that is applied to the arguments of the C# Main method. However, the parameters passed to the Main method are parsed a little bit differently in special situations, according to an unknown and undocumented algorithm.
member.param: If , the first argument (which is usually the file name of the program) is included, otherwise only the arguments after the first one are included.

member.name: P:Remotion.Text.IdentifierGenerator.CStyle
member.summary: Returns an identifier generator for C-style identifiers.

remarks.para: If you want to generate unique identifiers, use the method to create a new IdentifierGenerator.
C-style identifiers start with either an english letter or an underscore. All other characters can be english letters, digits or underscores. C-style identifiers are case-sensitive.
C-style identifiers can be used for the programming languages C, C++, C# and Java, among others. (Note that C# allows a number of unicode characters too, including languages-specific letters.)

member.name: T:Remotion.Utilities.Assertion
member.summary: Provides methods that throw an if an assertion fails.

remarks.para: This class contains methods that are conditional to the DEBUG and TRACE attributes ( and ).

Note that assertion expressions passed to these methods are not evaluated (read: executed) if the respective symbol are not defined during compilation, nor are the methods called. This increases performance for production builds, but make sure that your assertion expressions do not cause any side effects! See or and the for more information about conditional compilation.
Assertions are no replacement for checking input parameters of public methods (see ).

member.name: M:Remotion.Utilities.EqualityUtility.GetRotatedHashCode``2(``0,``1)
member.summary: Gets the hash code of the individual arguments, XOR'd with bits rotated.

remarks.para: This method XOR's the hash codes of all individual arguments in order to create a compound hash code for the entire set of arguments. Between XOR's, the compound hash code is rotated by 11 bits in order to better distribute hash codes of types that aggregate their hash results toward the least-significant side of the result (small numbers, booleans).
Overloads with type arguments are identical to the object-array version, they only reduce the amount of boxing going on (better performance).

member.summary: Checks two instances for logical equality, without considering the .
member.param: The left-hand side to compare.
The right-hand side to compare.

returns.para: True if the two objects are logically equivalent, ie., if they represent the same . This is very similar to the implementation of objects, but it ignores the property. In effect, two members compare equal if they are declared by the same type and denote the same member on that type. For generic objects, the generic arguments must be the same.
The idea for this method, but not the code, was taken from http://blogs.msdn.com/b/kingces/archive/2005/08/17/452774.aspx.

member.name: T:JetBrains.Annotations.ContractAnnotationAttribute
member.summary: Describes dependency between method input and output
member.syntax:
Function definition table syntax:
FDT ::= FDTRow [;FDTRow]*
FDTRow ::= Input => Output | Output <= Input
Input ::= ParameterName: Value [, Input]*
Output ::= [ParameterName: Value]* {halt|stop|void|nothing|Value}
Value ::= true | false | null | notnull | canbenull
If method has single input parameter, it's name could be omitted.
Using "halt" (or "void"/"nothing", which is the same) for method output means that methos doesn't return normally.
"canbenull" annotation is only applicable for output parameters.
You can use multiple [ContractAnnotation] for each FDT row, or use single attribute with rows separated by semicolon.

list.item: [ContractAnnotation("halt <= condition: false")] public void Assert(bool condition, string text) // Regular Assertion method
[ContractAnnotation("s:null => true")] public bool IsNullOrEmpty(string s) // String.IsNullOrEmpty
[ContractAnnotation("null => null; notnull => notnull")] public object Transform(object data) // Method which returns null if parameter is null, and not null if parameter is not null
[ContractAnnotation("s:null=>false; =>true,result:notnull; =>false, result:null")] public bool TryParse(string s, out Person result)

member.name: T:Remotion.Utilities.WorkContext
member.summary: Provides context information for error messages.

remarks.para:
Exceptions contain a stack trace of the time the exception was thrown, so it is easy to identify the code that caused the exception. However, there is no information as to which data this code was processing, or which iteration of a certain loop caused a problem. For programs that process large amount of data and fail for specific data, it can be tedious to find the state or data that caused an error.
WorkContexts provide an easy way to specify which data is currently being processed. In an exception handling block, the current context stack can be used to get diagnostic information about the state of the application when the exception occured.

member.summary: Leaves the context. .

member.name: M:Remotion.Utilities.WorkContext.Leave
member.summary: Leaves the context.

remarks.para: The context is left, but remains on the stack until the method is called, or a new context is entered. Therefore, the left context is still available for inspection (e.g. in an exception handling block).
A context that is left, but not done, is prefixed with a question mark in the context stack output. Use this information if you are not sure whether all calls to were coded correctly.
In C# it is generally recommended to use a using statement rather than calling Leave explicitly.

member.name: M:Remotion.Utilities.WorkContext.Done
member.summary: Marks the context as done.

remarks.para:
Call this method if the work within a context has been processed successfully (i.e., no uncaught exception has been raised).
For C# users, it is recommended to call this method at the end of the using block that contains the context.
